items.headline: Everyone, Everywhere Is Living Longer
items.description: One of the greatest achievements of humanity is the increase in life expectancy. In 1960, the average life span was 52.6 years. Today it’s an impressive 72 years. The reasons are simple: improvements in child survival, expanded access to healthcare (including widespread vaccination), and people being lifted out of extreme, grinding poverty. In the coming weeks and months, we’ll dive into more detail on all of these topics.

items.headline: Tuberculosis Deaths Are Falling Worldwide
items.description: Tuberculosis kills more people than any other infectious disease and accounts for about 20% of adult deaths in lower-income countries. But that number is falling fast. Vaccines have been key to this achievement - combined with early diagnosis, improved medicines, supportive social systems, and intensified research into treatments. Since 2000, these strategies have worked impressively. So much so, that the World Health Organization believes that tuberculosis can be eradicated entirely by 2035.

items.headline: Giant Panda Numbers Are Rebounding
items.description: Low birthrates, combined with human encroachment on habitat, have kept wild populations of giant panda bears low for many decades. But things are getting better for this rare and beloved creature. The International Union for the Conservation of Nature has reclassified the species from “endangered” to “vulnerable”. (That’s an upgrade, by the way.)

items.headline: Infant Deaths Have More Than Halved
items.description: The death rate of babies under the age of one has fallen hard in the last few decades. It's now probably at its lowest ever rate in human history. That’s thanks to many modern public health victories: better sanitation, more access to clean drinking water, enhanced nutrition, and the improved education of women.

items.headline: Stockholm Launched the World’s First Mental Health Ambulance
items.description: Even in the richest countries in the world, it’s difficult for people who suffer mental health problems to get proper care and treatment - especially in emergencies. Sweden’s capital, Stockholm, has launched an emergency response team solely for people in severe mental health or behavioural distress - situations which were traditionally handled by the police. The vehicle is staffed by two specialised psychiatric nurses and a paramedic from 3pm to 1am every day. In its first year of operation, the ambulance responded to 1,580 callouts. Treating mental health problems in the same way as physical health problems reduces stigmatisation of psychiatric illnesses, and helps people to reach out if they are suffering.

items.headline: Nearly 8% of the Ocean Is Now Protected
items.description: Our oceans face multiple threats - rising temperatures, agricultural run-off, overfishing and plastic pollution. But the good news is that more and more of the planet’s seas are being designated as protected areas, where marine ecosystems can thrive with minimal disruption. Nearly 17,000 different protected areas now collectively cover 28 million square kilometres. That’s a ten-fold increase since 2000.

items.headline: Women Can Finally Vote Everywhere
items.description: Well almost everywhere, anyway. The sole exceptions are Vatican City, which in 2011 had a grand total of 32 female citizens, and Brunei which has about 200,000. Vatican City is an absolute monarchy, headed by the Pope. It holds no elections, so neither male nor female citizens have the right to vote. However, the Pope is elected - by the College of Cardinals of the Catholic Church, which women cannot join. Brunei has a parliament, but hasn't held national elections since 1962. Both men and women aged 18 or older can vote in local elections for village leaders. Aside from that, every other woman in the world can now vote. If that’s not beautiful news, what is? Correction: This graphic previously listed Vatican City alone as the only country where women cannot vote. After some consideration, we've added Brunei due to the length of time since it last held national elections where women could vote.
items.tags: voting, women voting, women's rights, gender equality
items.source: J. Norberg, 'Progress: Ten Reasons to Look Forward to the Future' (2017)
items.twitter_text: If this isn’t @beautiful__news, then what is?
items.insta_text:
If this isn't @beautifulnews.daily, what is?

items.headline: Africa’s Longest War Is Finally Over: Ethiopia and Eritrea Make Peace After Decades of Conflict
items.description: Since 1998, the border between Ethiopia and Eritrea in eastern Africa has been closed as the two countries fought a long war over territory. However, in September 2018, the countries allowed certain land crossings to reopen. Embassies have reopened. Flights and phone calls can be made across the border. Since then Ethiopia, Eritrea and Somalia have signed a joint pledge to restore peace and stability. Ethiopia's prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, won the Nobel Peace Prize. Things are looking up in the region.

items.headline: Fewer Children Are Dying From Malaria
items.description: Malaria is an infectious disease carried by mosquitoes that can kill if left untreated. It’s one of the world’s most severe public health problems, and largely affects the poorest populations in lower-income countries. But over the last decade or so, the number of children dying from malaria has more than halved, thanks to a huge increase in funding and resources for malaria control around the world. If this trend continues, it should be possible to eliminate malaria in most of the world, or even the whole world, by 2050. Correction: In a previous version of this graphic, the squares were sized by length, not area. We've updated the image above with the correct sizings.

items.headline: 185 Countries Have Signed & Ratified the Paris Climate Agreement
items.description: The Paris Climate Agreement is humankind’s best chance of stopping runaway climate breakdown by 2050. This international treaty, negotiated over several years and agreed in Paris in 2015, was a feat of collaboration and diplomacy. Over 180 countries promised to plan ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions - and report regularly on their progress. Despite the United States’ headline-grabbing plans to withdraw from the agreement, many parts of the USA - individual states, counties and cities - have pledged that they’re “still in”.
items.tags: Paris Agreement, parties, member states, ratification, ratified, climate change, international agreements, global warming, United Nations, climate action

items.headline: We've Almost Eradicated Polio
items.description: Humanity has permanently eradicated a disease just twice in history - smallpox in the middle of the 20th century, and rinderpest (an agricultural disease affecting cattle) in the early 21st century. But polio is likely to be the third. Today, the disease exists in the wild in just two countries - Afghanistan and Pakistan.

items.headline: Sweden Sends Almost No Trash to Landfill
items.description: Most countries pile their trash up in huge heaps, or they bury it. But Sweden? Only one in every 200 tonnes ends up at a landfill site. The rest gets either recycled, turned into biogas, or poured into “district heating” plants that provide hot water and electricity to the biggest cities. Sweden’s need for trash is so large, in fact, that it imports hundreds of thousands of tonnes per year from neighbouring countries. Similar district heating systems are growing in popularity worldwide because they save money, reduce emissions, cut down on landfill and lower the need for fossil fuel imports. Beautiful.

items.headline: Global Suicide Rates Have Fallen by a Third
items.description: If you’re looking for evidence of an improving world, check out global suicide rates. Dramatic drops worldwide since 1994. Particularly steep declines in Russia, China and Japan. There’s no single reason for this. But social changes, along with restrictions on the sale of alcohol, painkillers and poisons, are helping to prevent suicide.
items.twitter_text: Falling suicide rates are one of the things improving in the world. Positive social changes, awareness and public policy help with prevention and give people hope for the future.
items.insta_text:

items.headline: Global Tree Cover Is Expanding
items.description: Deforestation in tropical areas (particularly in South America, Indonesia, and Sub-Saharan Africa) is being balanced out by the greening of China, India, Europe and North America. This doesn’t mean, unfortunately, that we can relax. Global tree cover is still far below where it was before humans came along. We need to halt tropical deforestation, as tropical forests hold loads of carbon and about half the world’s animal and plant species.

items.headline: 10 US States Are “Still In” the Paris Agreement
items.description: The Paris Climate Agreement, agreed by more than 180 countries in 2015, is humankind’s best chance of stopping runaway climate breakdown by 2050. In June 2017, United States president Donald Trump announced that the country would withdraw from the treaty, claiming that it would undermine the US economy. His decision was widely criticised across the political spectrum. Four days later, the “We Are Still In” declaration was launched, allowing leaders of US states, communities, tribes and businesses to pledge to honour the commitments of the treaty. Its signatories represent more than 155 million Americans, and $9 trillion of the US economy.
items.tags: paris agreement, climate change, global warming, international agreements
items.twitter_text: Trump wants out of the Paris Climate Agreement. But 10 states, representing over 155m Americans, have pledged to stay in.

items.headline: The World Has Gained a Fourth Type of Chocolate Outside of Dark, Milk & White – RUBY
items.description:
Ruby chocolate, invented in 2017 by Belgian-Swiss confectioner Barry Callebaut, is made from unfermented cocoa beans.

The exact process is a trade secret, but the result is a "sweet yet sour" taste: milkier than dark, fruitier than milk, and even sweeter than white chocolate.

items.headline: Air Travel Has Never Been Safer
items.description:
Despite the headlines, fatal accidents involving aircraft are rare. The number of fatal incidents per year is down to single figures. And in 2017, which saw over 33 million passenger flights, it was zero!

GPS technology has revolutionised air traffic control. Critical in-flight systems are protected. Pilots are rigorously trained and retrained again and again. Planes are more robust, and in-flight protocols are improving all the time. Flying is almost risk-free.
items.tags: air travel, flights, planes, aeroplanes, airplanes, plane crashes, flight safety
items.twitter_text: Despite the headlines, accidents involving aircraft are incredibly rare. The number of fatal incidents per year has been cut to single figures. Even zero!
items.insta_text:
Flying is almost risk-free.

In 2017, when there were over 33,000,000 registered carrier flights, the number of fatal incidents was zero. Why? GPS technology has revolutionised air traffic control. Critical in-flight systems are protected. Planes are more robust, and in-flight protocols are improving all the time. There’s no need to worry.

items.headline: A 100% Biodegradable, Comfortable Sanitary Pad Has Been Developed
items.description: Billions of sanitary products end up in landfill every year, taking centuries to decompose. But it doesn’t have to be this way. A team at the University of Utah have produced a pad that’s slim, plastic-free and breaks down in a matter of months. Greener to make, greener to dispose of. It’s a win-win.
items.tags: environmentally friendly materials, ecotech, periods, waste
items.twitter_text: Scientists have produced a sanitary pad that’s free of plastic and breaks down in months, instead of centuries. Greener to make, greener to dispose of. It’s a win-win.
items.insta_text:
It’s the greenest, slimmest, most compostable sanitary pad yet invented. 

Sanitary products usually end up in landfill, decomposing for hundreds of years. But this pad, made by a team at the University of Utah, breaks down in under six months. Greener to make, greener to dispose of. It’s a win-win.

items.headline: Female and Male Literacy Rates Have Almost Equalised
items.description:
In some parts of the world, educating women and girls hits a lot of resistance. It’s up against social barriers, cultural norms and family tradition. But it’s winning.

This isn’t just about reading and writing. Greater literacy means greater empowerment, which means less poverty, lower crime  and improved health. The gender literacy gap is set to narrow even more as access to education improves year on year, particularly in Southern Asia and Africa.
items.source: J. Norberg, 'Progress: Ten Reasons to Look Forward to the Future' (2017)
items.twitter_text: Literacy isn’t just about reading and writing. It leads to better health for women, less poverty, lower crime. So beautiful news: the gender literacy gap is narrowing.
items.insta_text:
Better access to education is narrowing the gender literacy gap. 📖

Female literacy is improving across the world, despite social barriers and cultural norms. This means better health, less poverty and growing opportunity.

items.headline: The USA Is Ripe for Wind Power
items.description:
Wind energy could fulfil the USA’s electricity needs ten times over. 

The windiest area? The Great Plains, which stretch from Montana down to the Mexican border. Even Texas already generates 15% of its electricity with wind, but it could easily provide enough for the whole country – and more.
items.tags: green energy, potential, future, climate change, global warming, green energy, carbon emissions, clean energy
items.twitter_text: Wind energy could fulfil the USA's electricity needs ten times over.
items.insta_text:
Wind energy could fulfil the USA's electricity needs ten times over. 💨

From Montana to the Mexican border, there’s huge potential for wind power. Texas already generates 15% of its electricity with wind, but it could provide enough for the whole nation – and more.

items.headline: Recycling 30 plastic bottles gets you a free trip on the Rome metro
items.description:
They call it Ricicli + Viaggi: Recycle + Travel. Three compactor machines, one on each of Rome’s three metro lines, gives a 5-cent credit for each bottle. Thirty bottles gets you a €1.50 ride!

Beautiful Rome is not renowned for the beauty of its recycling. But in the first 6 weeks of operation, these machines processed over 350,000 plastic bottles. Queues of people waited to swap them for €17,500 worth of free travel. Great idea + incentive = success!
items.tags: paper, waste, materials, landfill, plastic, oceans, transport, innovation, travel, governments
items.twitter_text: Ricicli + Viaggi (Recycle + Travel) has been a huge success. Each bottle gives you a 5-cent travel credit. People have been queueing to use the machines. 350,000 bottles were recycled in the first six weeks.
items.insta_text:
Give people the right encouragement, and they’ll recycle.

Rome is not renowned for its refuse and recycling facilities. But its new Ricicli + Viaggi scheme (Recycle + Travel) has changed everything. People receive a 5-cent travel credit for each plastic bottle. In six weeks, three compactor machines processed 350,000 bottles. Queues of people waited to swap them for €17,500 of free travel.

items.headline: Slavery is Illegal Almost Everywhere
items.description: Abolitionists of the late 18th century would be proud. Today, every country in the world has constitutionally banned slavery. Three, however, continue to violate the UN’s Universal Declaration on Human Rights by compelling citizens to work for no pay. North Korea is ranked the worst. The Uzbek and Turkmen cotton industries are also dependent on forced labour. Boycotts are ongoing, and are having an effect. Slavery should have no place in this world.
items.source: J. Norberg, 'Progress: Ten Reasons to Look Forward to the Future' (2017)
items.twitter_text: Slavery has no place in this world. All but one has officially criminalised slavery. A handful of others are under pressure to keep their promises to the UN.
items.insta_text:
Every country of the world has constitutionally banned slavery.

Abolitionists of the late 18th century would be proud. But three nations are still known to compel citizens to work for no pay, in violation of the UN’s Universal Declaration on Human Rights. North Korea is the worst offender. The Uzbek and Turkmen cotton industries are also dependent on forced labour, but boycotts are having an effect. Slavery should have no place in this world.

items.headline: Belize's Barrier Reef Is No Longer at Risk
items.description:
It spent ten years on UNESCO’s list of endangered world heritage sites. But after an extraordinary display of people power, Belize’s barrier reef is no longer in danger.

Threats of offshore oil drilling by the government were opposed by a people’s referendum, where 96% voted against it. Politicians listened. Now, with part of the largest reef in the northern hemisphere declared safe, habitats are guaranteed for many threatened species.
items.tags: oceans, coral, protected areas, marine life
items.twitter_text: Political will overturned by people power. Belize’s barrier reef was earmarked for offshore oil drilling, but now it’s been saved from destruction.
items.insta_text:
Sea turtles and manatees have been guaranteed a home in Belize.

After spending ten years on UNESCO’s list of endangered world heritage sites, Belize’s barrier reef is no longer in danger. Citizens of Belize voted overwhelmingly against offshore oil drilling, reversing policy and conserving part of the largest reef in the northern hemisphere.

items.headline: Armies Everywhere Are Shrinking
items.description: Every year, a smaller proportion of us serve in the armed forces. More sophisticated military tech is a big factor. And, also, despite headlines, overall, the world is a more peaceful, less war-torn place.
items.tags: soldiers, military personnel, wars, conflict, peace, fighting
items.source: S. Pinker, 'Better Angles of Our Nature' (2012)
items.twitter_text: Fewer civilians are needed by the global armed forces. The percentage has steadily declined ever since the Second World War.
items.insta_text:
Growing populations, but fewer soldiers. It’s been the trend since WWII.

Armies may recruit during outbreaks of conflict, but, the overall figures have continued to fall. Modern military techniques are more sophisticated. Tanks and submarines are being scrapped. Fewer people are needed on the battlefield.

items.headline: Norway Recycles Almost All of its Plastic Bottles
items.description:
In Norway, if you buy a plastic, it doesn’t belong to you. It’s just a lend. Once empty, you exchange it for cash or credit at a 'reverse vending machine'. Nationwide, if everyone's recycling rate hits 95%+, plastic producers pay no environmental tax.

Norway has met this target for seven years running. Just shows how person + business + incentives can produce results.
items.tags: paper, waste, materials, landfill, plastic, oceans
items.twitter_text: Bottle deposits and tax relief have allowed Norway to hit a 95% recycling target for seven years running. It’s an amazing achievement.
items.insta_text:
Recycling targets smashed – for seven years running. ♻️

In Norway, if you buy a bottle of something, the bottle doesn’t belong to you. It’s just a lend. When it’s empty, you exchange it for cash or credit at a reverse vending machine. If the nation recycles more than 95% over the year, plastic producers pay no environmental tax. It’s working. And any other country could do the same.

items.headline: Female Genital Mutilation is Declining Across Most of Africa
items.description: FGM is the ritual removal of external female genitalia. It affects girls and women of all ages, and originates from harmful ideas about purity, modesty and beauty. It was once common practice across 30 or so countries in Africa, Asia and the Middle East. International efforts to stamp it out since the 1970s have had mixed results.Thankfully, now it is declining - at least in Africa.
items.tags: violence against women, gender violence, female circumcision, cutting
items.twitter_text: The ritual removal of external female genitalia was once common across Africa, Asia and the Middle East. But this dangerous and painful custom is now firmly in decline.
items.insta_text: The ritual removal of female genitalia was once common across Africa, Asia and the Middle East. But this dangerous custom is now firmly in decline.

items.headline: US Prisoner Numbers Are Finally Declining
items.description:
Fewer arrests. Shorter sentences. More probation. More parole. After decades, the no. of inmates in American prisons is finally falling.

The US still houses more than 20% of the world’s prisoners. But changes in the criminal justice system at state and federal level are having an effect – and crime rates are dropping to historic lows in many states.
items.twitter_text: Changes in the US criminal justice system at state and federal level are finally having an effect. And crime is falling, too.
items.insta_text:
Fewer arrests. Shorter sentences. More probation. Falling crime. 🚔

After peaking in 2008, the number of inmates in American prisons is falling. The US still houses more than 20% of the world’s prisoners. But changes in the criminal justice system at state and federal level are having a pronounced effect.

items.headline: India's Solar Power Capacity Quadruples
items.description: With 300 sunny days a year, India has rightly put its heart into solar energy. In just three years it has become a market leader – third placed in the world.
items.tags: climate change, global warming, green energy, carbon emissions, solar capacity, clean energy
items.twitter_text: If you get 300 sunny days a year, a commitment to solar energy is a no-brainer. India has become a market leader in this essential tech.
items.insta_text:
If you’re getting 300 sunny days a year, solar energy is a no-brainer. ☀️

In three short years, India has become a market leader – third placed in the world. Its solar electricity is cheaper than its coal-fired equivalent. The International Solar Alliance is based there, promoting and developing solar energy products. Asian renewable energy has a bright future.

items.headline: The EU Has Banned Bee-Harming Pesticides
items.description: These chemicals, known as neonicotinoids, can no longer be used outdoors in the EU. Good. Because they direct disrupt bees’ learning and memory. Evidence is suggesting that the large-scale population decline of bees and, maybe, insects in general in related to the over-use of these pesticides.
items.tags: bees, pesticides, chemicals, farming, agriculture, insects, wildlife
items.twitter_text: Three #neonicotinoid chemicals which caused large-scale damage to bees can no longer be used outdoors in the EU. The environment thanks you.
items.insta_text:
If it's better for bees, it's better for all of us. 🐝

Three specific pesticides, known as neonicotinoids, affect bees’ learning and memory. Evidence indicates that they've caused large-scale population decline. But now there’s an outdoor ban in force across the EU. The environment will be thankful.

items.headline: How Denmark Plans to be Carbon Neutral by 2050
items.description: Here’s the Scandinavian blueprint for a modern “climate-neutral society”. The Danes are looking to be world leaders in the transition to post-carbon world. A great and helpful example for all of us to follow.
items.tags: carbon neutral, 2050, climate change, global warming, green energy, renewables, oil, wind power, wind energy, carbon emissions, climate action
items.twitter_text: The Danes are looking to be world leaders in the transition to green energy. And here’s the proof.
items.insta_text:
At last! A workable vision of a modern “climate-neutral society”. 💚

The Danes are looking to be world leaders in the transition to renewable  energy. Their “Together for a greener future” proposal brings together more than three dozen green initiatives.. It’s a great example for us to follow.

items.headline: Homicides Are Falling Around the World
items.description:
The risk of being murdered has been declining for a quarter of a century. Eastern Europe in particular has seen steep drops, by as much as 75%.

The reasons are hard to pin down, but society is improving in many ways. Greater rule of law. Better offender rehabilitation. Increasing literacy. And, crucially, self discipline. We simply have more respect and self discipline than we used to.
items.tags: murders, death, murder rates, violent crime, killings
items.twitter_text: In some parts of the world, the risk of being murdered has dropped by as much as 75%.
items.insta_text:
The reasons are hard to pin down. It’s a mix... 

The risk of being murdered has been declining steadily - with particularly steep drops in Eastern Europe. Why? Greater rule of law. Better offender rehabilitation. Increasing literacy. And even, crucially, self discipline. We simply have more respect for each other than we used to.

items.headline: More Than Half the World Now Lives in a Democracy
items.description: Over 30 years, democracies in the world have doubled. That means more voting, increased freedom of expression, greater civil liberties. 4.1 billion now live in a democracy, up from 1.8 bn in 1985. Of those who still live in autocratic regimes, four out of five live in China. Slowly, steadily, the world is gaining its freedom.
items.twitter_text: 4.1 bn people now live in a democracy, up from 1.8 bn in 1985. More voting. Greater civil liberties. Fewer autocracies. Democracy continues to rise.
items.insta_text:
4.1 n people now live in a democracy, up from 1.8 bn in 1985.

Since 1985, the number of democracies in the world has more than doubled. More voting, greater civil liberties. Of those who still live under autocratic regimes, 4/5 live in China. The world is slowly gaining its freedom.

items.headline: Every Single Country Has Seen a Reduction in Child Deaths (since 1950)
items.description:
Thanks to improvements in living standards, medicine, nutrition and sanitation, the battle against child mortality is being won. Since 1950, the global rate has declined by 80%. The gulf between higher and lower-income countries has narrowed.

It's brought happiness to families and saved literally millions of lives.
items.source: J. Norberg, 'Progress: Ten Reasons to Look Forward to the Future' (2017)
items.twitter_text: The battle against preventable deaths of children is being won. Thank you medicine, nutrition and sanitation. It’s a wonderful achievement.
items.insta_text:
The battle against preventable child deaths is being won, world-wide.

Thanks to improvements in living standards, medicine, nutrition and sanitation, the global rate has declined by 80% since 1950. The gulf between higher and lower-income countries has narrowed. It’s brought happiness to families and saved billions of lives. Now we need to go even further.

items.headline: Taiwan legalized same-sex marriage - the first Asian country to do so
items.description:
The Netherlands was the first country to permit same-sex marriage in 2001. Sixteen years later, Taiwan became the 28th nation to take this important, progressive step.

Next year, Costa Rica is due to say “I do” too. This is about human rights and democratic freedoms - and the welfare and happiness of LGBT citizens. Win win.
items.tags: homosexuality, gay rights, lgbtq rights, human rights
items.twitter_text: 28 countries have now legalised same-sex marriage. Next: Costa Rica
items.insta_text:
It's the 28th country to say “I do”.

The Netherlands was the first, in 2001. Next year, Costa Rica will become the 29th. This is about human rights and democratic freedoms. Each ruling has an incalculable impact on the welfare and happiness of LGBT citizens.

items.headline: Even Texas Is 32% Carbon Free
items.description: Texas might not be the greenest US state, but even this centre of oil and gas production is going renewable. Thanks to state policy, fossil fuels are contributing less and less to the Texan energy mix. Solar is on the rise. Wind is setting new records. The Green Star state?
items.tags: fossil-free, red state, climate change, global warming, fossil fuels, wind energy, wind power, solar energy, solar power
items.twitter_text: Thanks to state energy policy, Texas is shedding its gas-guzzling image. Wind and solar are the future.
items.insta_text:
Even gas-guzzling Texas is turning to green energy.

It may be the centre of American fossil fuel  production, but renewables are contributing more and more to the Texan energy mix. Solar is on the rise. Wind is setting new records. The Green Star state?

items.headline: Demand for Ivory Is Falling in China
items.description:
Ivory carving has taken place in China for thousands of years. But with demand fuelling illegal trade and a poaching crisis in Africa, the Chinese authorities were forced to act. In 2011, they banned the auction of all endangered species products.

Today, the only ivory auctions allowed in China are antique artworks. The domestic market for ivory has been shut down. Other countries now need to follow suit.
items.twitter_text: 8 years ago, China passed laws to shut down the domestic market for ivory. See the effect.
items.insta_text:
China passed laws in 2011 to shut down its market for ivory. It’s working.

Today, the only ivory sales allowed in China are of antique artworks. These measures were taking to help curb illegal trade and to alleviate the poaching crisis in Africa. Now other countries need to follow suit.

items.headline: Algeria, Argentina, Paraguay, and Uzbekistan are now malaria-free
items.description:
The WHO has certified 99 countries and territories to be free of malaria, a terrible disease that kills over 435,000 people globally every year.  Here are the latest four to join the club. They’ve all reported zero cases in the last five years.

Insecticide-treated nets and indoor spraying can have a dramatic effect on the incidence and spread of this terrible disease. Additional funding could even see malaria completely wiped out by 2050.
items.tags: vector, vector-borne disease, mosquito, bed nets, indoor residual spraying, mosquito protection, DEET, elimination, eradication
items.twitter_text: I’ve got 99 countries and malaria ain’t in one. Here are the latest four to be certified free of the disease.
items.insta_text:
Could malaria be completely eradicated over the next thirty years? 🤞

Ninety-nine countries are now completely free of this terrible disease. These four are just the most recent. Simple measures like insecticide-treated nets and indoor spraying can have a dramatic effect on its spread. It can be stopped. All it needs is more funding.

items.headline: Most of the World’s Population Is Protected by Domestic Violence Laws
items.description:
In the 1980s, few such laws existed. But today, 144 countries have criminalised domestic violence. Kenya, Bahrain and Algeria are amongst the most recent, but there are still some glaring omissions from that list – including Russia. 

With one in three women having experienced physical or sexual violence at the hands of her partner, more countries need to act. Victims need protecting.
items.tags: legislation, gender rights, equality, abuse, protection
items.twitter_text: One in three women has experienced physical or sexual violence at the hands of her partner. Most countries have recognised this in law. Now the rest – including Russia – need to follow suit.
items.insta_text:
1 in 3 women have experienced physical or sexual abuse from their partner.

In the 1980s, few domestic violence laws existed. But today, 144 countries have passed legislation to curb violence against women. Kenya, Bahrain and Algeria are amongst the most recent, but there are still some glaring omissions from the list, including Russia.

items.headline: African Countries Are Squashing Malaria
items.description:
90% of malaria cases occur in Africa. That’s 200m infections and 400,000 deaths, mainly children under the age of 5.  But the numbers are falling. Morocco and Algeria are now free of the disease, and many countries are heading in the same direction. 

How? Better public health information. Sleeping under insecticide-treated nets. Next-generation tools, including new insecticides and a partially-effective vaccine. Malaria can be beaten. Will be beaten.
items.tags: vector, vector-borne disease, mosquito, bed nets, indoor residual spraying, mosquito protection, DEET, elimination, eradication
items.twitter_text: Africa bears the brunt of malaria. 200m infections and 400,000 deaths, mainly children under the age of 5. But the disease can be beaten with better insecticides, better public health information and a new vaccine.
items.insta_text:
Eradicating malaria from the world is no longer a pipe dream.
 
90% of cases occur in Africa. That’s 200m infections and 400,000 deaths, mainly children under the age of 5. But the numbers are falling. Morocco and Algeria are malaria-free, and many countries are heading in the same direction. How? Better public health information. Sleeping under insecticide-treated nets. New chemical formulations for spraying. Partially-effective vaccines. Malaria can be beaten.

items.headline: Millions of lives have been saved by vaccines in the last 25 years
items.description:
Vaccines are one of the most cost-effective health technologies ever invented.

Between 1990 and 2016, global cases of measles fell by 93%. Diphtheria by 89%. Tetanus also by 89%. The death toll from common vaccine-preventable diseases dropped by 1.9 million. Here’s the truth: vaccines work.
items.tags: health tech, inoculations, preventable diseases, science, polio, measles, tuberculosis, tetanus
items.twitter_text: The death toll from common vaccine-preventable diseases has dropped by 1.9 million over 25 years. Vaccines work.
items.insta_text:
Vaccines are essential to keep the world healthy.

Between 1990 and 2016, global cases of measles fell by 93%. Diphtheria by 89%. The overall death toll from common vaccine-preventable diseases dropped by 1.9 million. They're one of the most cost-effective health tools ever invented.

items.headline: Iceland is the first country to legally mandate equal pay for men and women in the same role
items.description:
It’s now illegal to pay men more than women for doing the same job. If they do, they’ll be fined. Daily. 

The new law applies to every firm with 25+ employees. Iceland has long been ahead of the curve with regards to equality. As their social affairs minister says: “Equal rights are human rights.” They’ve now made a real commitment to closing the gender pay gap. Let’s hope others follow…
items.tags: pay gap, gender, fair pay, equality, laws, legislation
items.twitter_text: It’s now illegal to pay men more than women for doing the same job. If they do, they’ll be fined. Daily.
items.insta_text:
Companies that don’t conform are fined. Daily.

The new law applies to every firm with 25+ employees. Good old Iceland has long been ahead of the curve with regards to equality. As their social affairs minister says: “Equal rights are human rights.” They’ve now made a real commitment to closing the gender pay gap. Let’s hope others follow…

items.headline: We're Investing Twice as Much in Renewables vs Fossil Fuels
items.description:
Thanks to tougher policies to address the climate crisis, fossil fuels are gradually becoming yesterday’s source of energy. Since 2016, renewable power has seen twice as much investment as coal, oil and gas combined.

Better still: it's a global thing. Twenty percent of energy investment goes to China, driven by their low-carbon electricity efforts. In India,  funding for renewables now outstrips that of fossil fuels. Renewable energy is a-coming!
items.twitter_text: Dinosaurs! Fossil fuels are becoming yesterday’s energy. Since 2016, renewable power has seen twice as much investment as coal, oil and gas combined.
items.insta_text:
Green energy is the future.

Thanks to tougher policies to address the climate crisis, fossil fuels are becoming yesterday’s source of energy. Dinosaurs! Since 2016, renewable power has seen twice as much investment as coal, oil and gas. Better still: it's a global thing, with China and India upping their spending.

items.headline: More People Live Under Freedom of Information Laws Than Ever Before
items.description: Freedom of information is the idea that the public should always have access to data and information held by public authorities (government departments, health services, schools, police forces etc). In practice, it acts as a check on power - giving journalists and the public appropriate oversight of what authorities are doing. The United Nations tracks freedom of information laws and policies as part of its sustainable development goals. The number of countries with FOI laws has soared from 28 to 119 since 1999.
items.tags: information, censorship, internet, knowledge, laws, legislation, human rights
items.twitter_text: Freedom of information laws act as a check on power - giving journalists and the public oversight of what authorities are doing.
items.insta_text: Freedom of information laws act as a check on power - giving journalists and the public oversight of what authorities are doing.

items.headline: Smoking is Falling Fast in Japan
items.description:
15% of deaths worldwide are due to smoking. Tackling tobacco is the first step to making any nation healthier. Increased taxation and anti-smoking movements both play a major part. 

Japan has reduced the proportion of citizens who smoke by a third in just 20 years. Japanese men remain the heaviest smokers in the G7, but new laws outlawing the habit in public come into force in April 2020. The downward trend is set to continue.
items.tags: respiratory disease, lung disease, heart disease, smokers, smoking, cigarettes, tobacco, cancer
items.twitter_text: Increased taxation and anti-smoking laws have reduced the proportion of Japanese who smoke by a third.
items.insta_text:
You want to make a nation healthier? Tackle tobacco.

15% of deaths worldwide are due to smoking. Japanese men remain the heaviest smokers in the G7, but the proportion of Japanese who smoke has fallen by a third. How? Increased taxation, anti-smoking movements and new laws outlawing smoking in public spaces. The trend is set to continue.

items.headline: More Women Are in Parliaments Around The World
items.description:
Achieving gender equality means putting more women in positions of power. Some countries are doing brilliantly. Rwanda, Cuba, Bolivia - all have parliaments with more than 50% women. Others, like Haiti and Qatar, have none.

Women running for election are often disadvantaged by discrimination, intimidation and lack of funding. But globally, the trend is positive. Record numbers of women are now sitting in the Indian parliament and US Congress.
items.tags: political representation, leadership, gender equality, head of state women MPs, equal representation
items.twitter_text: Rwanda, Cuba and Bolivia have parliaments with more than 50% women. Others, like Haiti and Qatar, have none. But overall, the trend is positive. It’s good for society.
items.insta_text:
We need more women in positions of power. We’re getting there.

Gender equality depends on it. Some countries are doing brilliantly. Rwanda, Cuba and Bolivia have parliaments with more than 50% women. Others, like Haiti and Qatar, have none. Women running for election are often disadvantaged by discrimination, intimidation and lack of funding. But overall, the trend is positive. Record numbers of women now sit in the Indian parliament and US Congress.

items.headline: Almost Half of California's Electricity Now Comes From Renewables
items.description:
California has been a flag bearer for clean energy since the 1970s. Nine solar farms in the Mojave Desert. The largest wind farm in the USA. The biggest geothermal facilities in the world. If all other states followed, US greenhouse gases would be nearly 25% lower!

The state continues to lead the way by breaking renewable energy records and setting bold and bolder objectives. The latest: a goal of 100% zero-carbon electricity by the year 2045. Go for it!
items.tags: climate change, global warming, green energy, renewables, oil, carbon emissions, solar, clean energy
items.twitter_text: California has been a flag bearer for clean energy since the 1970s. If all other states had followed their example, US greenhouse gases would be nearly 25% lower.
items.insta_text:
9x solar farms. World’s largest wind farm. California - the flag bearer for clean energy! 🇺🇸

It has been since the 1970s. Nine solar facilities in the Mojave Desert. The largest wind farm in the USA. The biggest group of geothermal power plants in the world. If all other states followed California, US greenhouse gases would be nearly 25% lower. Its latest goal: 100% zero-carbon electricity by the year 2045.

items.headline: Suicides in Russia Are at a 50-Year Low
items.description: FACT: when alcohol is cheap and plentiful, suicides increase. Economic hardship and seismic social changes make things even worse. Russia knows this. 50% of its suicides are drink-related. But new policies on alcohol have led to real change. Binge drinking is down. The rate of suicide has halved. Many lives have been saved.
items.twitter_text: FACT: When alcohol is cheap and plentiful, suicides increase. Russia knows this only too well. But its new alcohol policies have cut the numbers dramatically.
items.insta_text:
FACT: cheap alcohol = increased suicides. Especially in Russia where 50% of suicides are drink-related...

Economic hardship and seismic social change have made things even worse. But new alcohol policies brought about real change. Less binge drinking. Rates of suicide have halved in Russia since the turn of the century.

items.headline: US Cancer Survival Rates Are Rising
items.description: The prevalence of cancer may be growing, but one thing is clear: the disease is steadily, gradually, being beaten in the USA. Five-year survival rates are improving.  Earlier detection + improved treatment = countless lives saved.
items.twitter_text: The prevalence of cancer may be growing, but it’s being beaten. Survival rates are up in the US. Earlier detection + improved treatment = countless lives saved.
items.insta_text:
Earlier detection + improved treatment = countless lives saved.

Five-year survival rates are improving at every stage of the disease. That means only one thing: cancer is being beaten in the US.

items.headline: Everything That Kills Children Is Declining
items.description: This is one of humanity’s greatest success stories. Child deaths worldwide have halved over the last twenty years. Because of vaccines, better medical treatments and more effective prevention. New vaccines will continue to reduce deaths from preventable diseases like pneumonia and diarrhoea. That means even more children survive and flourish.
items.tags: child mortality, disease, global health, diarrhoea, pneumonia, tetanus, measles, meningitis, sepsis
items.twitter_text: More children are surviving into adulthood than ever before. Thx to support and investment in medical treatments for simple, preventable diseases. New vaccines will see those numbers increase even more.
items.insta_text:
Preventable child deaths have halved - it’s one of humanity’s greatest success stories. 

Thanks to international collaboration on vaccines, better treatments and more effective prevention. More children than ever are surviving and reaching adulthood. And new vaccines have the potential to cut deaths even further. A true triumph.

items.headline: The UK's carbon emissions are falling fast
items.description: The UK is decarbonising faster than any other high-income country. How? Reduced dependence on coal. Massive investment in wind power. Homes and factories using less electricity. Businesses cutting fuel consumption. Without these changes, UK emissions would be double. Britannia Rules!
items.tags: clean energy, energy use, green energy, carbon

items.description:
Everyone should have equal access to education, housing, employment, healthcare with all cultural differences preserved. 

Protecting minorities is beneficial to everyone. It reduces poverty, speeds development and limits conflict. Only 17 countries still officially discriminate. Let’s get it to zero.

items.headline: More Nepalese Kids Are Going to Preprimary School Than Ever
items.description:
Education is an essential human right. But some countries struggle to provide it. The children of Nepal were failed by the caste system, political instability and natural disasters.

Then, in 2007, universal education was guaranteed in the Nepalese constitution. It meant millions more schoolchildren. Less poverty. Greater understanding. Better quality of life.

Education is a human right. 🎓 Our futures depend on it.

items.headline: China could generate half its power from renewables by 2040
items.description:
China uses more energy than any other country and emits the most carbon dioxide. But it’s going big on renewables. In fact, almost half the world’s investment in green power comes from China.

Within twenty years its wind power capacity will have doubled. Solar quadrupled. Dependence on coal and oil drastically reduced. The benefits will be felt by the whole planet.

items.headline: Oral rehydration therapy has saved millions of lives around the world
items.description:
Diarrhoea can be deadly. But there’s a solution. Literally.

A solution made of glucose and sodium, dissolved in water. It can be mixed at home and administered instantly. It’s saved tens of millions of lives since the 1960s. New formulas are proving even more effective. Simple and beautiful.
items.tags: ORS, ORT, oral rehydration therapy, diarrhoea, diarrhea, child mortality, medication, cheap solutions, oral rehydration salts, diarrhea treatment

A deadly disease. A simple solution. Literally. Glucose + sodium + water.🚰

Glucose and sodium, dissolved in water. It can be mixed at home and administered instantly. It’s saved tens of millions of lives since the 1960s, and new formulas are even more effective. It's one of the most important medical advances of the last 100 years.

items.headline: Angola, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria & Mozambique Have Halved Malnutrition
items.description:
Across the entirety of Africa, efforts to tackle malnutrition have blossomed. How? Special flour, fortified with vitamins and iron. Local activists educating communities. International NGOs improving food security. The steady, invisible efforts you won’t hear about in the media. 

Governments, farmers, traders, schools and hospitals all play a role. When they pull together, amazing things can happen.
items.tags: hunger, food poverty, nutrition, malnourished, health, stunting
items.source: J. Norberg, 'Progress: Ten Reasons to Look Forward to the Future' (2017)

items.insta_text:
Malnutrition in Africa can be beaten. For good.

Governments, farmers, traders, schools and hospitals all play a role. Local activists educating communities. International NGOs improving food security. Vitamin-fortified flour. These countries have shown what can be done when people work together.

items.headline: Far More Unites Us Than Divides Us
items.description:
The world population seems ever more divided and polarised, disaffected, separated. It’s us vs them, right? Well, wrong.

If you look under the hood, beyond the media presentation of the world, the truth is far less depressing.

A study of 86,000 people reveals that when it comes to morality, human values and trust, people across all backgrounds and all levels of society, almost completely agree with each other.

By gender, age, education, income, religion - no matter how you slice it, the similarity of attitudes between groups is greater than 90% on average.

If you focus on differences, you risk only seeing differences.
items.tags: religion, education, income, global family, united, together, values
items.twitter_text: “We are far more united and have far more in common with each other than things that divide us.” The late Jo Cox.
items.insta_text:
People have never been more divided, right? Um, wrong…

If you look beyond the media presentation of a polarised world, the reality is less depressing.

A study of 86,000 people reveals that when it comes to morality, human values and trust, people across all backgrounds and all levels of society, pretty much agree.

By gender, age, education, income, religion - no matter how you slice it, the similarity of attitudes between groups is greater than 90%.

If you focus on differences, you risk only seeing differences.

items.headline: The First Commercial, All-Electric, Passenger Aircraft Has Landed
items.description:
It may look odd. It may be small. But this aircraft changes everything. Abandoning jet fuel for electricity slashes the cost of short flights. And it’s great news for the environment.

In the future, larger hybrid planes will take off and land using electric power. That means lower CO2 emissions. They may be able to carry more passengers. And a new epoch might dawn for human travel.
items.tags: aircraft, emissions, clean energy, clean tech
items.twitter_text: It’s been delayed. But finally: an aeroplane powered by electricity, slashing emissions and the cost of air travel.
items.insta_text:
Electric aircraft? They thought it couldn't be done. ✈️

It may look odd, and it may be small. But the cost of powering it is tiny compared to the jet fuel equivalent. It’s great news for the environment. Longer term, electricity will power the take-off and landing of bigger, hybrid aircraft. That means lower CO2 emissions.

items.description:
They cost $2 each. They last for three years. They save lives.

Insecticide-treated nets are the most cost-effective way of preventing malaria. Hundreds of millions of them are distributed every year to protect people while they sleep.

items.headline: The US Could Massively Reduce Emissions Just by Swapping Beef for Beans
items.description:
15% of greenhouse gas emissions come from livestock farming. Half of humanity’s methane. 60% of its nitrous oxide. Both gases contribute to the climate crisis.

Beef is the foodstuff with the highest environmental impact. Beans are among the lowest. This simple data-thought experiment shows how a small dietary choice could make a big difference.
items.tags: diet, vegan, vegetarian, carbon footprint, legumes, meat
items.twitter_text: 15% of greenhouse gas emissions come from livestock farming. This simple data-thought experiment shows how a small dietary choice could make a big difference.
items.insta_text:
Changing our diet could smush emissions. A data-thought experiment.

How? 15% of greenhouse gases come from livestock farming. Half the world's methane. 60% of its nitrous oxide. They both contribute to the climate crisis. Beef is the foodstuff with the highest emissions. Beans are among the lowest. So just swap them!

items.headline: World Poverty is Lower Than You Think
items.description:
The number of people living in extreme poverty has halved. But that’s not the common perception. 

Why? The media rarely focuses on the positive. Pessimistic stories get more attention. We might think we know about the world, but the truth: we’re beating extreme poverty. The UN aims to end it completely by 2030.
items.tags: economic inequality, poor, low income, poverty line
items.twitter_text: Over the last 20 years, has world poverty increased? Stayed the same? Or dropped?
items.insta_text:
Extreme poverty has halved. We just don’t know it.

Our common perceptions of the world can be distorted. Why? The media rarely focuses on the positive. Pessimistic stories get more attention. But the UN now aims to end extreme poverty completely by 2030.

items.description: Cancer care and drug treatments are improving rapidly. The result? A dramatic extension of patient lifespan. The cost? A mere $125 for each year of life gained.

Never Been So Accurate
items.description:
A new test for cervical cancers has a 100% detection rate. In a clinical trial of over 15,000 women, it got a perfect score.

items.headline: Smoking Bans Have Improved Health
items.description:
Almost 100 countries prohibit smoking in public places. These bans induce a lot of grumbling from a small minority of smokers, but they deliver huge health benefits for everyone.

Heart attacks, respiratory infections, asthma and premature births are all down in countries that have introduced bans on smoking in public places.

Stubbing out saves lives.

items.insta_text:
Banning smoking saves lives.

items.headline: European Countries Are Banning Fur Farming
items.description:
It’s nearly 20 years since the UK banned fur farming. The rest of Europe has gradually followed suit, led by public concern about animal welfare and the ethics of the industry.

There’s only a handful of hold outs. Some countries have stopped short of bans, but have introduced laws to make the business unviable. People power CAN make a difference.

items.description: Atmospheric acidity is back to 1930’s levels. That means air quality is up. Clean air laws in the US and Europe have worked. It’s an amazing achievement.

items.headline: Not a single Mali desert elephant has been lost to poachers since a brigade to protect them was established
items.description:
Elephants are revered by local communities in Mali. But by 2016 poachers brought them to the edge of extinction. Just 300 were left. With the ivory trade taking advantage of lawlessness in desert regions, their chance of survival was slim.

An anti-poaching brigade was setup to defend them. It reduced the number of killings to zero.
items.twitter_text: A ruthless ivory trade left just 300 desert elephants in Mali. But the government stepped in, halting killings completely.
items.insta_text:
Poachers had brought Mali’s elephants to the edge of extinction.

The ivory trade took advantage of lawlessness in desert regions. But the government formed an anti-poaching brigade to defend the 300 that remained. This reduced the number of killings to zero. The elephants, so revered by local communities, were saved.

items.headline: Fewer Children Are Dying
items.description:
What a difference 200 years makes! Nearly half of children used to die before their fifth birthday. It’s now less than 4%. The gap is narrowing between higher and lower-income countries, too. Billions of lives saved.

How? Better living standards. Better medicine. Better nutrition. Better sanitation. They all improve our chances of survival into adulthood.

items.headline: Famine Deaths Have Plummeted Globally
items.description:
Famine poses less of a threat in the modern world. Why? Reduced poverty. Bigger agricultural yields. Better healthcare and sanitation. Improved monitoring systems to predict danger. 

War or oppressive governments are the main triggers of famine in the modern world. Increased democracy, stability and peace have lowered those risks, too. Result? Millions of lives saved.

items.description:
Giving is good. Period. And it helps reduce inequality around the world.

Overseas development aid has more than tripled in the last 20 years. Big increases from Japan, Russia,  Turkey and the UK. The EU has promised big donations to the Balkans and sub-Saharan Africa in the coming years. Aid austerity is reversing.

items.headline: More and more people are gaining access to electricity
items.description:
Electricity is essential for everything and a yardstick for decreasing poverty. Today it’s finally reaching places like rural India, Bangladesh and Kenya. 

(In Indonesia, 98% of the population have access to electricity. Thirty years ago it was just 62%.)

Now the number of people without electricity is well below one billion. That’s a record. There’s still huge work to do, particularly in Africa. But it’s possible the UN goal of electricity-for-all-by-2030 might just be met.

items.headline: Almost 4,500 Microgrids Are Planned or Installed Globally
items.description:
The main problem with renewables is that they provide intermittent energy, not continuous flows of energy like coal and gas. Our existing electrical power grids are not designed for energy levels that rise and fall like solar and wind. 

Enter microgrids - part of the transition to a post carbon world. They can be used on their own - in villages, communities or individual houses - or linked up to support the main ‘macrogrid’ when energy supply is variable.
items.tags: electricity, alternative grid, electricity access, remote access, rural access, energy
items.twitter_text: Solar and wind are powerful energy sources but supply intermittent energy, not continuous flows of energy like coal and gas. #Microgrids are part of the solution.

Our existing electrical power grids are not designed for energy levels that rise and fall. Micro grids can be used on their own - in villages, communities or individual houses - or linked up to support the main ‘macrogrid’ when energy supply is variable.

items.headline: These Countries are Crushing it at Recycling
items.description:
Germany has been the world’s best recycler since 2005. But now there’s a race for the top spot.

What gives all these countries the edge? Government funding. Landfill bans. Collection schemes. Incentives to encourage everyone to recycle. The result? Resources saved. Energy conserved. Environment protected.

items.headline: The HPV vaccine has slashed infections
items.description:
HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection. But it doesn’t have to be that way. The HPV vaccine has had a dramatic effect since its introduction in 2006. Fewer infections. Protection against many varieties of cancer. 

HPV is the most common sexually transmitted infection. But it doesn’t have to be. The HPV vaccine has dramatically reduced incidence over the last 15 years. 

More than 70 countries now routinely vaccinate against HPV. It's on the World Health Organisation’s list of essential medicines. It’s a stunning success for science.

items.description:
Bank accounts aren’t an option for most Africans. But thanks to mobile money, they don’t need one.

Smartphones have changed everything. The unbanked can send and receive cash. They can settle bills. Get their wages. Buy goods and services. Save. Invest. 

More money moves from mobile phones in sub-Saharan Africa than anywhere in the world. It’s leading the fintech revolution.

items.headline: There's finally a vaccine for Ebola and it Really Works
items.description:
Ebola is no longer an incurable horror disease. Thanks to Canadian scientists.

The new vaccine, rVSV-ZEBOV, was used in the last outbreak in the Republic of Congo. It protected over 90,000. Health responders deployed it in social rings: firstly those in contact with known cases, then their contacts. It’s the same strategy used against smallpox 40 years ago. And that was wiped out.
items.tags: inoculations, innovation, healthcare, health tech, NTDs, neglected tropical disease

First: those in contact with known cases. Then their contacts. It’s the same strategy used against smallpox 40 years ago. And that disease was wiped out.

items.headline: It's Tougher Than Ever To Escape Justice For Rape
items.description: So-called “marry your rapist” laws were once common. Men could be exonerated from rape charges if they married the victim, or offered to marry her. Reform of this appalling injustice began in the 1970s. Country after country repealed legislation. In the space of a month in 2017, Tunisia, Jordan and Lebanon changed their laws. Now just a handful need to be overturned.
items.tags: punishment, law, legal reforms, protection, consent, sexual violence, rape culture

Country after country repealed legislation. In the space of a month in 2017, Tunisia, Jordan and Lebanon changed their laws. Now just a handful remain.

items.headline: Most One-Year-Olds Are Now Vaccinated Against Three Lethal Diseases
items.description: The vaccine is called DPT and it’s saved millions of lives. This is about good information buttressed with good immunisation programs.
items.tags: infants, child mortality, babies, vaccination coverage, diptheria, tetanus, pertussis, whooping cough, kids

Three diseases. One vaccine. Vital protection.

It’s known as DPT. It has overpowered diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough. Millions of lives saved. Poorer countries tend to have lower coverage, but it doesn’t always follow. This is the success of good information and good immunisation programs.

items.headline: Mountain Gorilla Populations Are Rising
items.description: Only one species of great ape has a growing population: mountain gorillas. In fact, they've been pulled back from the brink of extinction. That’s down to intensive conservation work and community engagement in Uganda, Rwanda and the DRC. They’re still critically endangered, but now possibly have a brighter future.
items.twitter_text: Mountain gorillas are the only great ape with a growing population. That’s down to intensive conservation work and community engagement.
items.insta_text:
It’s the only great ape with a growing population. 🦍

Mountain gorillas have been pulled back from the brink of extinction. That’s down to intensive conservation work and community engagement in Uganda, Rwanda and the DRC. They’re still critically endangered, but now they have a brighter future.

items.headline: Paper Recycling in Europe Has Almost Doubled Over 25 Years
items.description: In the World (Biodegradable) Cup of paper recycling, Europe is smashing it. Nearly 3/4 of paper products are recycled. 17 countries are hitting the 70% mark. Paper fibres are recycled 3.6 times – that’s 50% more than the world average. Saving energy. Reducing landfill. Conserving resources.
items.tags: paper, waste, materials, landfill, plastic, oceans
items.twitter_text: With 3/4 of paper products recycled, Europe is way ahead of the rest of the world.
items.insta_text:
In the World Cup of paper recycling, Europe is smashing it. 🏆♻️

items.headline: 59 Countries Have Completely Banned Corporal Punishment
items.description: Violence towards children causes long-term damage to the individual and to society. 59 countries have now outlawed physical punishment at home and in school.
items.twitter_text: 59 countries have now made the pledge to outlaw physical punishment everywhere: at home and in school.
items.insta_text:
Violence towards children causes long-term damage to the individual and to society. 

59 countries have now made a pledge to protect children from hitting, caning and other physical forms of punishment. Europe and South America are taking the lead.

items.headline: Every Year We're Adding More and More Solar Power
items.description: Solar is truly becoming a mainstream source of electricity. Over 24 countries can now generate a gigawatt or more. Costs are falling. Demand is rising. The transition is beginning.

items.headline: We're Eliminating Malaria Worldwide
items.description:
No malaria cases for three years running? Your country can apply for a special ‘disease eliminated’ status. 99 have been certified by the WHO so far. That’s huge. 

By developing and deploying vaccines and new strategies, this terrible disease that infects tens of millions might even be wiped out by 2050.
items.tags: vector, vector-borne disease, mosquito, bed nets, indoor residual spraying, mosquito protection, DEET, elimination, eradication
items.twitter_text: The WHO has granted malaria-free status to 99 countries so far. That’s huge. New vaccines and strategies could see it WIPED OUT by 2050.
items.insta_text:
We’re beating malaria, one country at a time.

99 countries and territories are free of this terrible disease. That’s huge. By developing and deploying vaccines and new strategies, it could be WIPED OUT by 2050.

items.headline: An Australian Company Has Invented a Bee-Friendly Insecticide
items.description: We need bees for pollination. We need insecticides. But the two don’t always mix. A solution: bio-insecticides. Sero-X is made using peptides from the butterfly pea plant. It does the job. It’s benign to use. And if it’s safer for bees, it’s better for us all.
items.tags: insects, bees, pollination, organophosphates, pyrethroids, carbamates, alternative insecticide, eco-friendly
items.twitter_text: When bees are dying, that’s a problem. Bio-insecticides such as Sero-X can help.

Bio-insecticides are kinder to bees. 🐝

Sero-X is made using peptides from the butterfly pea plant. It does the job. It’s benign to use. And if it’s safer for bees, it’s better for us all.

items.headline: The Bangladesh population living in extreme poverty has dropped from 40% to 14%.
items.description: Bangladesh is on track to leave the UN’s list of Least Developed Countries. Thousands of km of roads have been improved. Electricity now reaches remote areas. There’s 90% enrolment in primary schools. Greater literacy, higher food production, longer life expectancy. All in one generation. An amazing transformation.

items.headline: Road travel in the US is safer than ever
items.description:
More drivers, more cars, more journeys. Fewer deaths per mile.

How? Research, legislation, education. We know seatbelts are good, drink driving is bad. Vehicles have airbags and antilock brakes. Roads have rumble strips and safety barriers. Net result: hundreds of thousands of lives saved.
items.tags: road safety, car accidents, road accidents
items.twitter_text: Cars and roads are safer. Laws are tighter. People are wiser. Lives saved, injuries prevented.

items.headline: Indigenous Communities Are Safeguarding the World's Forests
items.description:
Indigenous peoples have managed forests for generations. Protecting habitats. Conserving resources. Keeping ecosystems in balance. 

The threat from agribusiness and mining is real, but these communities still control 1/5 of the world’s forest carbon. It’s in good hands. Lands can be regenerated and deforestation restricted. Net result: emissions reduced.
items.twitter_text: Indigenous communities have managed forests for generations. They’re good at it. Habitats are protected. Resources conserved. Ecosystems kept in balance.
items.insta_text:
Who’s best at managing forests? 🌳🌳 Governments? Corporations? Or indigenous peoples?

No prizes. The people who live on the land have been protecting habitats, conserving resources and keeping ecosystems in balance for generations. The threat from agribusiness and mining is real, but these communities are regenerating land and limiting deforestation. Net result: lower emissions for the world.

items.headline: Nordic Countries Are the Happiest
items.description:
What makes a happy country? Decent incomes. Longer lives. No corruption. Good governance. Having people to count on.

Nordic nations score highly when it comes to social care. Strong communities, neighbourly trust, state support for those in need. And if you rank the happiness of immigrants? The very same countries come out on top.
items.twitter_text: Decent incomes. Longer lives. Good governance. Strong communities. Nordic nations always score the highest. Their immigrants are the happiest in the world, too.
items.insta_text:
A caring nation is a happy nation. That is, literally, science. 🇳🇴🇫🇮🇩🇰🇮🇸

Nordic countries are known for strong communities, neighbourly trust and state support for those in need. They also have decent incomes, low corruption and good governance. And if you rank the happiness of immigrants? The very same countries come out on top.

items.headline: Biofortified Cassava Is Set to Transform the Health of Millions
items.description:
Diets in lower income countries can lack choice. A single staple crop might give people enough energy. But enough nutrients?

Children and pregnant women need zinc and iron to avoid diarrhoea and anaemia. Cassava doesn’t have much of either. But US biologists have found a way of genetically modifying it to boost its nutritional value. Science magic!
items.tags: staple crop, biofortified, GMO, modified, zinc, iron, engineered
items.twitter_text: Children and pregnant women need zinc and iron to avoid diarrhoea and anaemia. Cassava has little of either. But a genetically modified version could change lives in countries where it’s the staple crop.
items.insta_text:
Cassava was low in zinc and iron. Then bio-geneticists got to work...

It’s the staple crop in many parts of sub-Saharan Africa. It gives energy. But lacks nutrients like zinc and iron which help prevent disease in children and pregnant women.

items.headline: A Quarter of the World Now Has Tax-Free Menstrual Products
items.description:
In some parts of the world tampons are taxed more heavily than hotel bookings, truffles or caviar. Despite being a necessity.

Ireland, Jamaica and a handful of other countries never had such a tax. Some, including the UK and Germany, reduced it. Others, like Kenya and India, abolished it. The realisation is long overdue: feminine hygiene is not a choice.
items.tags: tampon tax, period tax, feminine hygiene
items.twitter_text: In some parts of the world, menstrual products are still taxed more heavily than hotel bookings, truffles or caviar.
items.insta_text:
Is the tampon tax on its way out? 🔴

Some countries tax menstrual products more heavily than hotel bookings, truffles or caviar. But five never had a tax. And nine have now abolished it. The realisation is long overdue: feminine hygiene is not a choice.

items.headline: 30 countries could be 100% geothermal powered
items.description:
Geothermal energy comes from the heat in the crust of the earth. It’s renewable. Stable. Available 24/7. It doesn’t even need much land for extraction. 

The best geothermal fields are in volcanically active areas, particularly the Pacific Rim. Costs are falling. Capacity is growing. The potential is massive.
items.tags: clean energy, green energy, heat pumps, underground
items.twitter_text: Geothermal energy has huge potential in volcanically active areas. It’s naturally replenished. And unlike solar or wind, it’s available 24/7.
items.insta_text:
Geothermal energy has volcanic potential. 🌋
Where tectonic plates meet, geothermal is at its most potent. It’s a renewable source like no other. It’s available 24/7. Costs are falling. Capacity is growing.

items.headline: Almost Half of New Cars Sold in Norway Are Electric
items.description:
Norway’s leading the electric vehicle revolution. It’s been giving incentives to EV owners for 30 years. Lower taxes. Tolls waived. Free parking. And massive investment in charging stations. 

The country aimed to get 50,000 EVs on the road by 2018. It hit the target three years early. It now aims to stop sales of petrol cars by 2025.
items.tags: cars, emissions, clean energy, clean tech
items.twitter_text: Norway’s leading the electric vehicle revolution. How? Incentives and infrastructure. It’s smashing its targets.

items.headline: Leprosy Is on the Way Out
items.description:
Mythbust! Leprosy can’t be spread by casual touch. It isn’t hereditary. And it's curable within a year with the right medicine. Stopping the ignorance & stigma, though, is crucial for early diagnosis.

And that’s happening now. Multi-drug therapy has reduced the number of global cases by 75% in 20 years. 16 million patients have been treated. Leprosy is no longer considered a public health problem. By 2020, it could be eradicated completely. Beautiful.
items.tags: health, communicable diseases, treatment, healthcare, eradication, elimination
items.twitter_text: Leprosy is curable within a year with the right multi-drug therapy. Global cases have tumbled by 75% in 20 years. It could be eradicated by 2020!
items.insta_text:
Ignore the myths. Leprosy is totally curable.

Stopping the stigma is crucial. Leprosy isn't hereditary. It can’t be spread through casual touch. 16 million patients have been treated, and it's no longer a public health problem. By 2020, it could be eradicated completely.

items.description:
When you eliminate borders, you break down barriers. This e-passport gives new freedom to more than a billion Africans. 

They’ll be allowed to live, work, learn and love across a continent of 30,000,000 sq km. More trade. Deeper integration. A symbol of African unity.

items.description:
It’s called Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). It could be part of our strategy to alleviate the climate crisis. And Iceland has cracked it. 

The process transforms CO2 from a greenhouse gas into a harmless mineral. Fast, cheap and permanent. This is 21st century alchemy.

items.headline: Even More AIDS Sufferers Are Being Treated & Infections Continue to Decline
items.description:
When HIV is suppressed, it can’t be passed on. That’s the finding of a landmark study. And it could signal an eventual end to the pandemic.

Anti-retroviral drugs are effective enough to render HIV untransmittable. Reducing stigma. Challenging discrimination. Saving lives.

items.description: For the first time in conservation history, there’s some good news for tigers. From an all-time low in 2010, numbers are on the increase. items.headline: Yearly Hours Spent on Housework Have Plummeted in the US
items.description:
The time Americans spend cooking and cleaning has fallen dramatically. Laundry time has been halved. Household utilities barely need maintaining. Clothes mending is almost non-existent.

It’s down to technology. Kitchen appliances. Harder-wearing floors and surfaces. New fabrics. Better food storage. In some ways, life is easier.

items.headline: Millions of Children's Lives Have Been Saved
items.description: One direct effect of human progress is longer lives. 100 years ago, nearly half the world’s children died before the age of 5. Today it’s less than 4%. Meaning millions have had a chance at life. That’s progress.
items.twitter_text: From 1990 to 2015, over 270,000 fewer children died every year. Human progress = longer lives.
items.insta_text:
One direct effect of human progress is longer lives.

100 years ago, nearly half the world’s children would die before the age of 5. Today it’s less than 4%. Thanks to better education, less violence, declining poverty, and greater understanding of nutrition and medicine. These improvements continue.

items.description: This Dutch innovation could revolutionise road building. Prefabricated sections, just dropped in. Easier maintenance. Space for cables, pipes, sensors, solar heating. No digging. Less disruption. And all made out of 100% recycled plastic. Pilots are already underway.

items.headline: Guinea Worm Disease Is Almost Eradicated
items.description:
It’s a dreadful infection caused by drinking contaminated water. It’s infected 300,000 people since the year 2000. But it could become the second disease in human history to be completely eradicated. 

Unlike smallpox, it has no vaccine nor medical treatment. This achievement will be solely down to education.  Teaching people to filter water. Helping and investing in communities. Changing behaviour.
items.twitter_text: After smallpox, guinea worm disease looks set to become the second in human history to be completely eradicated.
items.insta_text:
This disease is almost wiped out – and by education alone. 

Guinea worm is a dreadful disease caused by drinking contaminated water. But it could become the second in human history to be completely eradicated. Unlike smallpox, there’s no vaccine or medicine. This achievement is down to education. Teaching people to filter water. Helping communities. Changing behaviour.

items.headline: The WHO Has Taken Trans Identities Off Its List of Mental Health Disorders
items.description:
Trans people identify with a gender that differs from their sex. Prejudice against them is real. They encounter violence, discrimination and social disadvantage.  Understanding of their needs is growing, though. 

From January 2022, the World Health Organisation will no longer classify gender incongruence as a disorder. The aim: to reduce stigma while ensuring access to healthcare. Gender identity isn’t a lifestyle choice.
items.twitter_text: Understanding of gender incongruence is growing. The World Health Organisation is reclassifying it from January 2022.
items.insta_text:

The World Health Organisation is reclassifying the condition from January 2022. The aim: to reduce stigma while ensuring access to healthcare. Gender identity is not a lifestyle choice.

items.headline: Major Fashion Brands Are Going Fur-Free
items.description:
Change has been building for decades. Activists and supermodels have spoken out. Animal rights organisations have lobbied. The fashion industry has gradually responded with more accountability, more transparency, and, above all, *less fur*.

Sales have fallen by 18% in the last five years. Awareness is growing. Demand is falling.

items.description: Women running for election around the world are up against it. Discrimination, intimidation, lack of campaign funding. But trends are increasingly positive. items.headline: Coating Solar Panels with Carbon Nanotubes Can Triple Efficiency
items.description: Solar cells are only 22% efficient. A lot of that wasted energy is lost through heat. But scientists at Rice University in Texas have found an answer to the problem: carbon nanotubes. Just a millionth of a millimetre across, these tiny tubes can turn that heat back into light. Energy recycled at source. More electricity generated.

items.description:

items.headline: Violent Crime Has Almost Halved in the US Since 1995
items.description:

The perception of the public may be different, but the evidence is clear. We’re living in one of the least violent periods of American history.

items.description:

There are still big gaps between nations. But they’re closing. By 2050 they may have disappeared altogether.  100% global literacy? It’s within reach.

items.headline: The UK Is Cutting Coal Use, Fast
items.description:

The UK had well over 3,500 hours of coal-free electricity in 2019. (More than 150 days’ worth.) These lower emissions mean genuine progress towards meeting the Paris Agreement.

items.description:
Antiretroviral drugs have crushed HIV/AIDS. Deaths and new infections have been cut in half. Those with the disease can live normal lives. HIV has been suppressed to levels where it can’t be passed on. 

The latest drugs require a lower dosage, so the cost of treatment is falling. The UN has promised more resources, too. The battle is being won.

items.description:

items.description: Swine flu had never been seen before. It spread quickly. A pandemic was announced after 58 days. But response plans had been made. Vaccines were developed. Systems put in place, from community to international level. 16 months later, the WHO declared the pandemic over.

items.headline: Extreme Poverty Is Almost Eradicated in the East Asia and Pacific Region
items.description:
It was once the poorest region in the world. But the skyrocketing rise in living standards in East Asia is unparalleled. The number of people living in extreme poverty fell almost a billion between 1990 and 2013.

China and Thailand have become upper-middle income countries, with the vast populations of Indonesia and the Philippines not far behind. Education and economic development have been the main drivers. Plus lower unemployment and greater public investment.
