items.description:

items.headline: We Can Generate Light from Darkness
items.description:
The thermoelectric generator is a simple device with huge potential. At night, the top gets cold. The bottom stays warm. That difference in heat generates a tiny electric current. 

Right now it’s just enough to power a light bulb. But it’s free energy. One day it could bring renewable night-time power to remote areas everywhere.

items.headline: Child Deaths in Rwanda Have Plummeted
items.description:
Malaria. Diarrhoea. Pneumonia. Malnutrition. These preventable conditions were killing Rwanda’s children. So the country changed tack. More health workers. Vaccination programmes. Health insurance schemes. Better communication. 

Between 2000 and 2015, Rwanda experienced the world’s biggest fall in infant mortality. The UN estimates that the lives of 590,000 children were saved. That is beautiful news.

items.headline: Livestock Fed Seaweed Emit Less Methane
items.description:
The global population of cows and sheep is growing fast, emitting a huge amount of greenhouse gases. Scientists have tried vaccines, selective breeding and dietary supplements, but nothing can reduce the methane.

However, promising new research shows that low doses of limu kohu – a seaweed used in Hawaiian cooking – drastically cuts the production of methane by ruminants. If the plant could be farmed and fed to the world’s livestock, it could cut their emissions by nearly 30%.

items.description:

items.description:
Trees are good for the planet, good for all of us. We need more of them. Much more.

Ecosia was launched in 2009. It donates 80% of its advertising profits to tree-planting schemes. It publishes monthly financial reports to show the world what it’s doing. So far: 82.5 million trees across 22 projects and 17 countries. Now THAT’S environmental action.

items.headline: Biodiversity Is Flourishing in the River Thames
items.description:
The Thames was biologically dead. An open sewer. No oxygen, no life. In the 1960s, the clean-up began. Better sewage management. Industry regulations. Pesticide bans. 

The fish slowly returned, along with dolphins, porpoises and seals. Now it's an important marine habitat. It’s breathing again.

items.headline: Suicide Attempts Among LGBT Teens Fell After Same-Sex Marriage Was Legalised
items.description:
Suicide is the second leading cause of death amongst young people in the USA. Sexual minorities are particularly at risk. But when a state recognised same-sex marriage, the LGBT suicide rate fell. States that didn’t legislate saw no such fall. 

The causal link can’t be proven. But these laws promote dignity and equality. Perhaps that gives hope when it’s most needed?

items.description:
Most crops have an internal glitch. Instead of grabbing CO2 to convert to sugars, they sometimes grab oxygen by accident. They use up energy dealing with that mistake. It impairs their growth.

American scientists have found a way to patch this bug. Plants become 40% more productive. Estimated additional yield in the US MidWest alone? Enough to feed 200 million people.

items.description:
Most of the HIV infections in children are transmitted from the mother. It can happen during pregnancy, childbirth or even breastfeeding.

items.headline: The Death Penalty is Disappearing
items.description:
The death penalty is revenge, not justice. It can be used as a political weapon. It discriminates against minorities and the poor. Mistakes can happen. And it’s never been proven to deter crime. 

Any country that executes people is committing the same violence it condemns. But laws are changing. The number of executions is falling.

items.headline: Nations Agree to Protect 2.8m sqkm of Arctic Ocean
items.description:
The Arctic has one of the most fragile ecosystems in the world. As the ice melts, it could be destroyed by unregulated commercial fishing. 

The beautiful news?  All the countries with coastal claims – and many others – have agreed to take a big step back. It’s the precautionary principle in action. Science first. Fishing later.

items.headline: Phasing Out HFCs Will Cut Climate Change by 0.5°C
items.description:
The 1987 Montreal Protocol was a global agreement to protect the atmosphere from ozone-layer-destroying CFCs. But their chemical cousins, HFCs, are the new challenge. Their use has been soaring, particularly in India and China.

An amendment to the Protocol, agreed in 2016 in Kigali, Rwanda, puts a reduction plan in place for the next 20 years. They’ll be phased out. Replaced with safer alternatives, like hydrocarbons and ammonia. Better for the planet. Better for everyone. And a feat of international cooperation.

items.description:
Juvenile crime has plummeted in California. Fewer arrests. Detention centres emptying. Lower crime rates overall.

Why? No one knows for sure. It could be down to new youth programmes. Falling demand for crack cocaine. Tougher sentences for gang members. Or the lead-crime hypothesis – that declining pollution is improving behaviour. Regardless, it’s good news for the Golden State.

items.headline: Life Expectancy in Africa is Soaring
items.description:
Improved healthcare. Cheaper drugs. Better food security. Advances in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. Rising GDP per capita. They’ve all helped Africans live longer. 

Since 2000, life expectancy at birth is up by more than 20% in Uganda, Ethiopia and Kenya. More than 30% in Rwanda, Botswana and Sierra Leone.

items.headline: Canada Created the Largest Protected Coniferous Forest on the Planet
items.description:
Canada is home to some of the largest areas of intact forest in the world. Four new designated parks have created a protected area twice the size of Belgium. 

No logging, drilling or mining allowed in this 6.7m hectare conservation zone. This kind of action doesn’t just help trees – it also protects animals such as bison, caribou, peregrine falcons.

items.headline: Fewer US Women Are Dying of Breast Cancer
items.description:
Breast cancer is the second most common cancer among women in the USA. But better treatment and detection are helping to slash death rates.

Earlier screening. Growing awareness of symptoms. A better understanding of genetic susceptibility. Safer medications. Over 375,000 deaths have been averted in the last three decades alone.

items.description:
These intelligent, socially complex mammals swim as much as a hundred miles a day in the wild. In captivity they’re deprived of space, stimulation and social contact.

Thankfully, their display for human entertainment is winding up. Legislation is being passed to either ban the practice, restrict it or make it unprofitable.

items.headline: Bangladesh Has Flourished Since Independence
items.description:
50 years ago, Bangladesh was in crisis. Ravaged by war, chronic malnutrition, a shattered economy. But thanks to foreign aid and forward-thinking policies, it’s been transformed.

It’s almost self-sufficient in food. Disease is declining, industry thriving, per capita income rising. Women have been given a greater voice. That’s led – amongst other things – to improvements in children’s health and education. The entire society is benefiting – and the numbers show it.

items.description:

Geothermal energy is available all day, every day. It’s stable and renewable. And there’s lots of it.

items.headline: Ingenious Concrete-Filled Trains Act as Giant Batteries
items.description:
Energy production ebbs and flows, particularly renewables. But energy grids need continuous energy to sustain flow. As we switch to clean energy, we need ways of storing excess power so we can use and distribute it when we need it.

That’s what this system promises. It’s cheaper than any other form of electricity storage, and it claims to be 80% efficient. An entire grid could be stabilised using a fleet of concrete-laden trains. Kinda crazy. Definitely clever.

items.headline: Curbing Illegal Logging Has Saved Millions of Butterflies
items.description:
Every year, 60 million butterflies visit The Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve to spend the winter. Tree branches sag under their weight, colouring swathes of the forest orange.

Illegal logging placed them in peril. But when an environmental police force of 1,000 officers was deployed by the Mexican government, logging fell by 94%. A World Heritage Site was protected.

items.headline: European Teens Are Drinking Less Alcohol
items.description:
Risky drinking can lead to violence, injury and STDs. In the longer term it leads to psychological and social problems.

Europe has seen significant declines in teenage drinking over the last twenty years. Higher taxes, restrictions on advertising and information campaigns have been the drivers. The result? Healthier and happier adolescents.

items.headline: Rice Can Now Be Grown in Salty Water
items.description:
China has 1 million square km of soil (an area the size of Nigeria) that's too salty for crops. They’ve tried for over 40 years to produce salt-resistant rice with a decent yield that will grow there - without success. Until now.

This new variety – Yuan Mi – produces more than 4.5 tonnes per hectare. That’s 2/3 the yield of normal rice. A barren wasteland can become arable land. Boosting rice production. Feeding people.

It was thought that UK wind farms wouldn’t be able to beat gas-fired power stations on price until 2030. That could now happen as soon as 2023. Clean energy looks like a bargain. Bye bye, fossils!

The Prospera program improved health and education for millions of Mexicans. Also, more social cohesion. Less disease. A reduction in income poverty. Little wonder that dozens of countries followed Mexico’s lead.

items.headline: Dutch Prisons Are Closing
items.description:
The Netherlands has the third lowest incarceration rate in Europe. Fines, mediation and rehabilitation programmes replace jail terms. The state even had to import prisoners from Belgium and Norway to keep its prison officers employed!

Now empty prisons are being turned into asylum centres, houses and hotels. Under this more humane system, crime rates continue to fall.

Residential lighting was just 5% LED in 2013. Now it’s at least 40% and growing. Illuminating!

items.headline: Drones Have Revolutionised Medical Deliveries in Rwanda
items.description:
Getting medicine to remote parts of Africa isn’t easy. Drones change everything. Flying at 100km/h, they can cut a treacherous 4-hour road journey to just 30 minutes.

Drones delivered 5,500 units of blood to Rwandan regional hospitals over a 12-month period. It led to a reduction in maternal deaths. Fewer cases of malaria-induced anaemia. Rwanda is leading the way.

items.headline: Eighteen Countries And Territories Have Eliminated Lymphatic Filariasis
items.description:
It’s a disease caused by microscopic worms and spread by mosquitoes. It can lead to horrific swelling of limbs (lymphedema) and hardening of the skin (elephantiasis). 

In 2000 it was endemic in 81 countries. The World Health Organisation launched a global programme to fight it. 7.7 billion treatments were delivered to 910 million people. Eighteen countries and territories have eliminated it so far. Seven more are imminent.

items.description:

Information campaigns to tackle diarrhoea-related diseases. Vaccines to cut cases of tuberculosis, tetanus and diphtheria. Polio, once endemic, has been eradicated. Healthier kids. Healthier mothers. Happier families.

items.headline: Black incarceration rates are finally falling in the US
items.description:
African Americans suffer disproportionately under the US justice system. But their rate of imprisonment is declining. It’s now at the lowest level since the early 1990s. 

This is partly down to overall crime rates falling, partly down to criminal justice reform in the inner cities where harsher punishments have been reined in.

items.headline: South Korea is the First Asian Nation to Announce a Green Deal
items.description:
South Korea is currently the world’s seventh largest carbon emitter. Coal represents 40% of its energy mix. But a landslide victory by the Democratic Party in the 2020 elections has set a “Green New Deal" in motion. 

Phasing out of coal financing at home and abroad. A new carbon tax. A new body to support workers transitioning to green jobs. Steering the country towards decarbonisation. It’s the first East Asian country to make such a broad commitment.

items.headline: China Is Eradicating Extreme Poverty
items.description:
40 years ago, 9 in 10 Chinese people lived in poverty. Today, the majority do not. No other country has done anything like it.

items.headline: Spain Leads in Concentrated Solar Power
items.description:
There’s solar power using photovoltaic panels. And then there’s concentrated solar power (CSP), where mirrors reflect the sun to a focal point. Spain embraced the technology in 2008 and remains the world leader.

This green energy currently supplies up to 10% of Spain’s energy. The technology is being exported worldwide. A Greenpeace study estimates that CSP could account for up to 25% of the world’s energy requirements by 2050. Go Spain!

items.headline: More US Women Are Moving Into Science, Tech, Engineering & Math Occupations
items.description:
Science, technology, engineering and mathematics. There’s always been a discrepancy between the numbers of men and women employed in these sectors. Gender stereotyping is partly to blame. That imbalance is now being redressed.

American groups are encouraging girls to take STEM successes at school to higher education. That way, the gender gap will keep closing. The scientific community will become more open and diverse.

items.headline: South Africa is Cutting HIV Infections
items.description:
South Africa has the biggest HIV epidemic. It also has the world’s largest antiretroviral treatment programme, costing more than $1.5bn per year. It has extended life expectancy from 56 in 2010 to 63 in 2018.

And that’s not all they’ve done. Better testing (90% of South Africans living with HIV are now aware of their status.) Improved HIV education. Preventing mother to child transmission. Condom distribution. By 2022, the country aims to cut the number of new infections to under 100,000 per year.
items.twitter_text: HIV is no match for testing, treatment & education. By 2022, South Africa aims to cut the number of new infections to under 100,000 per year.
items.insta_text:
Can South Africa reduce new HIV cases to 100,000 per year? 🇿🇦

It has the world’s largest antiretroviral treatment programme, costing more than $1.54bn per year. It’s improved HIV education, testing and condom distribution. The measures are working. The life expectancy of South Africans has extended from 56 in 2010 to 63 in 2018.

items.headline: A Global Effort to Restore 350m Hectares of Land is on Track to Succeed
items.description: It’s estimated that 30% of the world’s arable land suffers from degradation. The Bonn Challenge is about restoring it. This doesn’t just benefit the environment. It makes economic sense, too. Trillions of dollars can be gained by managing land, protecting forests, conserving soil and water. It could improve the lives of 3 billion people.

items.headline: Finland Is Teaching its Schoolkids to Identify Fake News
items.description:
Actual fake news (as opposed to truths that politicians find inconvenient) is a modern scourge. Facts, particularly scientific facts, end up disregarded. This poses significant economic and democratic risks.

The Finns are fighting it with critical thinking. Teaching young people how to recognise disinformation, hoaxes and conspiracy theories. Finland now has the best media literacy in Europe. That means greater resilience to information warfare.

items.headline: Afghanistan Built 16,000 Schools in 12 Years and Literacy is Up
items.description:
Secular education didn’t exist under the Taliban. Girls were denied schooling altogether. The future for young Afghans looked bleak. But a new regime, together with international donors and development agencies, rebuilt the education system.

16,000 new schools. 154,000 extra teachers. Millions more students (40% of whom are girls). Rising literacy rates. Better prospects for the country.

items.description:
The potential of green energy is amazing. Combined, it’s already the world’s second largest source of electricity. But so much more carbon-free energy is there for the taking.

Emissions could be slashed. Fossil fuel consumption could be cut to near zero. Countless socio-economic and environmental benefits. It’s a no brainer.

items.description: Marine protected areas were first established in the 80’s. They now cover nearly 8% of the world’s oceans, and include marine parks, nature reserves, reefs, even shipwrecks and archeological sites. Preserving natural and cultural resources, encouraging biodiversity. Good for the ocean. Good for us.

items.description: Healthy life expectancy = the years of good health a person can expect. Thanks to science and technology, this number is rising nearly everywhere. Better medicines. items.headline: A natural substance could compete with the herbicide glyphosate
items.description:
Modern agriculture needs weedkillers. Glyphosate is one of them. It’s used all over the world, but questions have been raised about its safety, including its persistence in the environment.

This sugar molecule, discovered at the University of Tübingen in Germany, outperformed glyphosate in early tests. It inhibits plant growth, but it's harmless to humans. Non-toxic. No controversy. Could be a winner.

items.headline: A New Device Can Harness Electricity from Raindrops
items.description:
Water hitting a surface can generate tiny amounts of electricity. Scientists at City University of Hong Kong have taken that idea and created a usable, renewable power source.

It could be deployed on all kinds of surfaces that come into contact with water. The hull of a ferry. The top of an umbrella. The inside of a bottle. Another ingenious way to harness natural energy.

items.headline: Worm-related diseases have fallen drastically in Kenya
items.description:
Parasites can starve people of nutrients, leading to malnutrition and infection. Children become more susceptible to diarrhoea. Pregnant women are stricken by anaemia. 

In Kenya, information campaigns, mass administration of deworming tablets and better all-round hygiene have all played a part to slash this terrible burden and create a healthier nation.

items.headline: More Indonesians than Ever Have Access to Clean, Safe Cooking Fuel
items.description:
Large parts of the world have no access to modern cooking fuels such as electricity or LPG (liquid petroleum gas). Billions of people still use the dirtier wood, coal or kerosene. The resulting indoor pollution can cause illness and respiratory disease. 

Indonesia launched a massive Clean Stove initiative in 2012. The nation was encouraged to switch from kerosene to clean-burning LPG. Cooking became cheaper, healthier and more convenient. Healthier homes. Lives transformed.

items.headline: Air Pollution Has Plummeted Across Many Major Cities
items.description:
With lockdowns in place, businesses closed and transport at a standstill, air quality has been soaring. Delhi, the 5th most polluted city in the world, has seen a 60% decline in airborne pollutants.

It doesn’t solve the long term problem of toxic air. But it does show how city life could improve if environmental concerns were addressed more urgently.

items.headline: There Are Already At Least 76 Coronavirus Vaccine Candidates
items.description:
The race to produce a vaccine is underway. The genetic sequence of SARS-CoV-2  was published on 11th January. Every week sees progress, preliminary trials and further collaboration. 

Vaccine development has a high failure rate, so the more approaches there are, the greater the chance of success. Some human trials have already begun. This is the fastest vaccine development in history.

items.headline: Far Fewer Traffic Accidents and Fatalities on California's Roads
items.description:
California has the largest number of vehicles in the USA, and has the crash fatality rates to match. But since the state locked down on March 20th, there’s been an unparalleled fall in road deaths and injuries.

When crashes do happen, emergency vehicles can attend faster. The cash savings (property damage, healthcare, emergency services, lost time at work) already total around $1bn.

items.headline: China is Banning the Consumption of Dogs and Cats
items.description:
Concern about the spread of disease has never been higher. China has responded with curbs on the wildlife trade and a new whitelist of animals allowed to be raised for meat. Dogs and cats are not on it. 

Somewhere between 10m and 20m dogs and 4m cats are killed in China for food every year. These numbers should now fall dramatically. There are still concerns about loopholes in the new guidelines, but it’s a step in the right direction for both animal welfare and human health.

items.headline: The Cholera Vaccine is Reaching More People than Ever
items.description:
If drinking water is clean and there’s proper sanitation, cholera can’t get a foothold. Where there’s poverty and political instability, it thrives.

In 2013, the World Health Organisation stockpiled millions of doses of cholera vaccines. They became a lifeline in areas where sanitation couldn't immediately be improved.

items.headline: Plastic-Eating Worms Could Tackle Trash
items.description:
We discard millions of tons of plastic every year, creating a waste crisis. Many potential solutions are on the table. One unusual one is to use bugs. Lots and lots of bugs.

Mealworms – usually used as fishing bait and pet food – can actually digest styrofoam. Waxworms can eat polyethylene, the world’s most common plastic. One day, on a vast scale, natural organisms may be able to process our unnatural plastic back into its natural components.

items.headline: The US is Steadily Adopting Renewable Energy Goals
items.description: Initiatives such as ‘We Are Still In’ have galvanized climate change commitments across the USA. The Ready For 100 movement goes even further. Its vision: a country running entirely on clean, renewable energy by 2050. It’s slowly happening, from the ground up. Students, volunteers, parents, mayors, CEOs, all getting involved. More than 100 cities have adopted the goal so far. Six have already hit the target.

items.headline: Zika Disappearing From The Americas
items.description: Zika, a virus spread by mosquitoes, arrived in Brazil in 2015. Its potential to cause abnormalities and disabilities in children caused panic. The epidemic spread quickly across two continents. Hundreds of thousands of people were infected. There is still no treatment. But its spread has declined massively. Further outbreaks in the near future are unlikely. Viruses can (and do) die out.

items.headline: Most of the World Can Now Afford Mobile Internet
items.description: Internet access has become a modern human right. It’s needed to access basic public services, to stay informed, to communicate. Mobile data has often been unaffordable in lower-income countries. But that’s changing. New national broadband plans. Expansion of 3G and 4G coverage. Number portability. Millions of people getting connected, cheaply.

items.headline: The citizens of Mumbai conducted the largest beach clean-up in human history, removing more than 4000 tonnes of rubbish. Turtles born on beach in Mumbai for first time in 20 years.
items.description:
Mumbai’s Versova Beach had become a dumping ground for plastic. In 2016, a local lawyer – Afroz Shah – led a clean-up operation. Over 4,000 tons of waste was cleared by volunteers over a two year period. The coastline was transformed.

The Olive Ridley species of turtle – classified as vulnerable – returned to the beach shortly afterwards. Eggs were laid, hatchlings emerged. Their new home continues to be maintained by citizens groups, contractors and volunteers. People power!

Their new home continues to be maintained by citizens groups, contractors and volunteers. People power!
